page.title: Logos and uniforms of the Pittsburgh Steelers

rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1: â
<!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[File:Pittsburgh Steelers logo.svg|thumb|right|100px|Team logo based around the [[Steelmark]] logo, 1963-Present.]] -->
 
The [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] were founded [[1933 NFL season|in 1933]]. Over the course of the team's history, the team has had several logos while wearing virtually the same uniforms over the years, with subtle changes made to give the uniforms an updated look. The team colors, uniforms, and logo are often ranked as being among the best in the [[National Football League|NFL]].<ref>http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2005/writers/jay_mohr/11/09/mohr.sports/1.html</ref>
The [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] were founded [[1933 NFL season|in 1933]]. Over the course of the team's history, the team has had several logos while wearing virtually the same uniforms over the years, with subtle changes made to give the uniforms an updated look. The team colors, uniforms, and logo are often ranked as being among the best in the [[National Football League|NFL]].<ref>http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2005/writers/jay_mohr/11/09/mohr.sports/1.html</ref>
Line 8: Line 7:
The Steelers have had several logos in the early part of their history, among them including the [[Crest (heraldry)|crest]] of Pittsburgh, a football with Pittsburgh's then-[[smog]]gy skyline, as well as a [[construction worker]] hanging onto a chain holding a [[Pennon|pennant]]. Another logo showed the worker [[punt (football)|punting]] a football on a [[Beam (structure)|steel beam]]. It is rumored that controversial mascot Steely McBeam was based on the latter logo.<ref>http://chriscreamer.com/team.php?id=156</ref>
The Steelers have had several logos in the early part of their history, among them including the [[Crest (heraldry)|crest]] of Pittsburgh, a football with Pittsburgh's then-[[smog]]gy skyline, as well as a [[construction worker]] hanging onto a chain holding a [[Pennon|pennant]]. Another logo showed the worker [[punt (football)|punting]] a football on a [[Beam (structure)|steel beam]]. It is rumored that controversial mascot Steely McBeam was based on the latter logo.<ref>http://chriscreamer.com/team.php?id=156</ref>
â
Since 1963, the team has used a [[Stencil (typeface)|stencil]] typeface for their script logo. Since then, many team-related typefaces have used stencil font.[[Image:Pittsburgh Steelers logo.svg|thumb|150px|right|The [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] logo is a variation of the Steelmark]]
+
Since 1963, the team has used a [[Stencil (typeface)|stencil]] typeface for their script logo. Since then, many team-related typefaces have used stencil font.
The team's current primary logo was introduced in 1962 and is based on the flag originally designed by Pittsburgh's [[U.S. Steel]] and now owned by the [[American Iron and Steel Institute]] (AISI). [[BrownsâSteelers rivalry|Ironically]], it was [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]]-based [[Republic Steel]] that suggested the Steelers adopt the industry logo. It consists of the word "Steelers" surrounded by three [[astroid]]s ([[hypocycloid]]s of four [[cusp (singularity)|cusp]]s). The original meanings behind the astroids were, "Steel lightens your work, brightens your leisure, and widens your world." Later, the colors came to represent the ingredients used in the steel-making process: yellow for coal, orange for iron ore, and blue for scrap steel.<ref>[http://www.steel.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home&TEMPLATE=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm&CONTENTID=12452 AISI | The Story Behind the Pittsburgh Steelers Logo<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> While the formal Steelmark logo contains only the word "Steel," the team was given permission to add "ers" in 1963 after a petition against AISI.
The team's current primary logo was introduced in 1962 and is based on the flag originally designed by Pittsburgh's [[U.S. Steel]] and now owned by the [[American Iron and Steel Institute]] (AISI). [[BrownsâSteelers rivalry|Ironically]], it was [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]]-based [[Republic Steel]] that suggested the Steelers adopt the industry logo. It consists of the word "Steelers" surrounded by three [[astroid]]s ([[hypocycloid]]s of four [[cusp (singularity)|cusp]]s). The original meanings behind the astroids were, "Steel lightens your work, brightens your leisure, and widens your world." Later, the colors came to represent the ingredients used in the steel-making process: yellow for coal, orange for iron ore, and blue for scrap steel.<ref>[http://www.steel.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home&TEMPLATE=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm&CONTENTID=12452 AISI | The Story Behind the Pittsburgh Steelers Logo<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> While the formal Steelmark logo contains only the word "Steel," the team was given permission to add "ers" in 1963 after a petition against AISI.
